i'm a master's student in computer science at eindhoven university of technology and the work that i'll be presenting
today is part of my master's thesis so in this talk i'll be occasionally
referring to pci express terminology um but enter in the interest of time in
case you're not familiar with it just think of pci express as a package choice network that connects your cpu
to your peripherals now thunderbolt is a external pcie-based interconnect
and it was developed by intel apple in 2011 now being pcie based it enables start
memory access io to the peripherals and so it's the first external
interconnect that allows use cases such as connecting a external gpu to a laptop connecting 5k
monitors accessing high speed external storage at its maximum
and performance well the first two versions they were mostly exclusive to max and use the mini display for form
factor uh thunderbolt 3 is the first version to be widely adopted among both
pcs and macs and it uses the usbc form factor instead thereby allowing not
only thunderbolt devices but also displayport and usbc
now dma is a very powerful concept um it enables
high bandwidth low latency use cases by putting the burden on the peripheral for
copying the requested data in directly into system ram but at the same time uh this could also
pose a security risk and this was actually the case with thunderbolt one um for fundable one all the attacker had
to do was basically connect a peripheral and then get unrestricted reading right memory
access now as a result the attacker could get
well excess data from encrypted drives and uh to gain persistent access they
could install a root kit dma attacks are generally well
understood first started with firewire back in 2004
and over the years gradually moved to pci express including all its form factors such as
m2 express card and eventually thunderbolt
so the threat model that we'll be talking about tonight is pre-physical access to a victim system
also known as an evil might attack and some of the real world scenarios that you can think of are
for example leaving a laptop unattended in a hotel room while you're
out for dinner or a desktop system sitting in an office
and at some point any cleaning crew comes in and has brief unfettered access now in case
you're wondering what such an evil clean crew might look like um i included a picture right here in the
slide so this pre-physical axis the industry has
implemented several protection measures over the years to protect against this so-called
opportunistic physical access so let's briefly go through them first one is really
simple you put a password on your bios and well that should prevent the attacker
from making unauthorized modifications uh when you get physical access then
there's secure boot secure boot focuses on cryptography
verifying all components in the entire buching starting from the os bootloader to the kernel
and finally device drivers there's boot card which focuses on
cryptographically verifying at the bios itself and there's full disk encryption um
which enables you to encrypt all your data so that when a attacker gets physical
access to your laptop they can disassemble the ssd but still cannot access the data with now
without knowing the correct password now to counter the dma attacks that
we've seen in the previous slide intel introduced what they call thunderbolt security levels
and these security levels are intended to protect the entire thing that you see right here
so let's dive a little bit deeper in the thunderbolt security architecture um security levels it's really
uh an access control system so if uh if you connect a device to the laptop
then as a user you will see this pop-up right here uh it will let you identify the device
and then make a decision whether you know whether or not you would like to enable pcie tunneling
now thunderbolt security levels rely on thunderbolt devices authenticating to
the host and these devices do this using the parameters shown right here and the
most important one being the universal unique id or uuid
now this number is intended to uniquely identify any single thunderbolt device
and also it's defined to be fused in silicon so it shouldn't be easy to change
so thunderbolt security levels is a multi-step system um as a user you can select any of these
in the bios um so let's uh quickly go through them um well sl0 basically is
no security so essentially the same situation like with thunderbolt one there's so one user um where device
authorization is based on the device uid um and this is actually the default
settings uh on all thunderbolt equipped pcs then there is so2
it's the same as as a one but it adds john's response mechanism
so3 disables all thunderbolt connectivity but allows usb and displayport devices
so4 is intended for use with thunderbolt docks so when you connect to dock you cannot
daisy chain any additional thunderbolt bolt devices um through the dock
and finally if you're using so1 or so2 you will get pre-boot protection for
free so that means that any authorized any devices that you've previously
authorized will also be usable during boot time while the rest will be blocked from
accessing your system now security levels um the security
level scheme is mostly known for protecting against the fights to host ema attacks but
since it prevents malicious devices from accessing the pcie bus
it actually prevents against other inherent attack factors such as well peer-to-peer dma attacks
uh pcied spoofing to target vulnerable device drivers and um tlp source id spoofing
so concept wise security level is really a powerful and much needed protection scheme
right so um introducing thunderspy so previous research you can roughly divide
into two categories um the first one before security levels
they primarily focus on pcie level dma attacks after the introduction of security
levels they mostly focus on tricking the user into accepting
